item.title: Video Analysis of ICE Shooting Sheds Light on Contested Moments
item.description: Newly available videos and existing footage synchronized and assessed by The Times provides a millisecond by millisecond look at how an ICE officer ended up shooting and killing a motorist in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Was Renee Good Obligated to Comply With an ICE Agent’s Orders?
item.description: The agent told Ms. Good to get out of her car before she was fatally shot. Legal experts said immigration agents may sometimes, but not always, have the authority to make such commands.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Renee Good. She was shot after beginning to drive away from an ICE agent who told her to get out of her car.

item.title: Did a Supreme Court Loss Embolden Trump on the Insurrection Act?
item.description: In refusing to let the president deploy National Guard troops in Illinois under an obscure law, the justices may have made him more apt to invoke greater powers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis on Monday night.

item.title: U.S. Says It Erred in Deporting Student Traveling for Thanksgiving
item.description: The Trump administration acknowledged it mistakenly deported a college student to Honduras despite a court order barring the removal. But the government has not moved to drop the case.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's lawyer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucía López Belloza’s high school graduation in Texas. She was detained and later deported in late November while trying to surprise her family with a visit.

item.title: Machado Presents Trump With Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader’s efforts to share her award with the U.S. president have shaken some Norwegians’ faith in their signature soft-power tool.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado outside the U.S. Capitol in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Delivers State of the Union Address
item.description: In her State of the Union address, Delcy Rodríguez echoed her predecessors’ fiery rhetoric but tried to hew to President Trump’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Patricia Sulbarán
item.media:credit: Ariana Cubillos/Associated Press
item.media:description: Venezuela’s interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, delivering a speech at the National Assembly in Caracas on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Forces Seize Sixth Oil Tanker Linked to Venezuela
item.description: The Coast Guard boarded and seized the Russian-flagged tanker, originally named Veronica, in a pre-dawn operation in the Caribbean Sea.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Nicholas Nehamas and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: US Southern Command, via Reuters
item.media:description: An image from video released by the U.S. military showing the oil tanker Galileo, previously named Veronica, in the Caribbean on Thursday.

item.title: Battles Over Truth Rage Online Amid Iran’s Internet Blackout
item.description: The shutdown of online discourse within Iran has allowed both the government and its critics to flood social media outside the country with disinformation campaigns and fake images.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: via Associated Press
item.media:description: A frame grab from footage circulating on social media showing protesters dancing and cheering in Tehran last week.

item.title: How Activists in Iran Are Using Starlink to Stay Online
item.description: Activists spent years preparing for a communications blackout in Iran, smuggling in Starlink satellite internet systems and making digital shutdowns harder for the authorities to enforce.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Middle East Images/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Starlink receiver atop a house in Kurdistan, Iran, in 2023. About 50,000 Starlink terminals are now in the country, according to digital activists.

item.title: Israel and Arab Nations Ask Trump to Refrain From Attacking Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel asked the president to postpone any planned attack. Israeli and Arab officials fear Iran could retaliate by striking their countries.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with President Trump last month in Florida. The Israeli leader spoke to Mr. Trump on Wednesday, the same day that the president claimed Iran had stopped killing protesters.

item.title: Many Fiery Remarks, Little Clarity on What’s Next at Security Council Meeting on Iran
item.description: Iran’s representative denied the country had killed protesters, as the U.S. ambassador said President Trump had made clear “all options are on the table” to stop the killing.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmad Batebi, right, a human-rights activist, delivered remarks at the United Nations Security Council meeting on Iran on Thursday.

item.title: Taiwan Strikes Trade Deal with Trump, Vows More U.S. Chip Factories
item.description: The United States agreed to lower tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 to 15 percent, while Taiwan says it will invest in more chip manufacturing in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Amy Chang Chien and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Wen-Yee Lee/Reuters
item.media:description: Taiwan manufactures most of the world’s advanced semiconductors.

item.title: Trump Administration Lawsuit Seeking California Voter Data Is Dismissed
item.description: The Justice Department has sued about two dozen states over access to voter rolls, as the federal government pushes to create a national database.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Rylee Kirk
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in Los Angeles last year. A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that the Justice Department had filed against California last year demanding access to voter data.

item.title: What Did the White House and Denmark Agree to on Greenland? Depends Whom You Ask.
item.description: The White House and Denmark contradicted each other in public about what they had agreed to this week as President Trump continued to demand U.S. ownership of Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Jeffrey Gettleman and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: A Danish military vessel sailing near the old harbor of Nuuk, Greenland’s capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: Pentagon Will ‘Refocus’ Military Publication Stars and Stripes
item.description: The agency’s chief spokesman outlined plans to intervene in the previously independent newspaper’s coverage.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Godfrey/Associated Press
item.media:description: Two soldiers from the 25th Infantry Division reading an issue of Stars and Stripes in Cu Chi, South Vietnam, in 1969. The military newspaper has been published continuously since 1942.

item.title: Former Senator Kyrsten Sinema Accused of Affair With Member of Security Team
item.description: In a lawsuit, the ex-wife of Ms. Sinema’s onetime staff member accused her of showering him with gifts and breaking up their marriage.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Senator Kyrsten Sinema at the Capitol last month.

item.title: None of Mamdani’s Deputy Mayors Are Black. It Has Become a Problem.
item.description: Some Black and Latino leaders worry they are being denied access to power under Mayor Zohran Mamdani and that they may lose the ground they had gained under former Mayor Eric Adams.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani on Thursday announced Afua Atta-Mensah, who led his campaign outreach to Black voters, as the director of the Mayor’s Office of Equity and Racial Justice.

item.title: Number of Businesses in New York City Plunged Last Spring, Report Says
item.description: Roughly 8,400 businesses closed in the second quarter of 2025, according to the most recent city data, creating the largest net decline in business activity since before the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty storefront in Lower Manhattan. The drop-off in New York City business activity was most pronounced in major commercial districts, according to the Economic Development Corporation.

item.title: Nydia Velázquez Gives Mamdani a Warning as She Endorses a Successor
item.description: The veteran congresswoman said she would like Antonio Reynoso, the Brooklyn borough president, to replace her after she retires. She also said the mayor should stay out of political races.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Nydia M. Velázquez was an early backer of Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s campaign.

item.title: Why Trump Always Thanks You ‘For Your Attention to This Matter’
item.description: How a simple catchphrase sums up the president’s theory of executive power.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott

item.title: Uber’s Quest to Crack Japan Leads Through a Rural Hot-Springs Town
item.description: The ride-hailing giant’s chief executive has made a bet on how it can finally grab a bigger piece of one of the world’s largest taxi markets.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: Nick Reiner Was in a Mental Health Conservatorship in 2020
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who is accused of killing his parents, was under a yearlong legal arrangement that allows for involuntary psychiatric treatment.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango, Julia Jacobs, Ellen Barry and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Richard Shotwell/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nick Reiner was charged with two counts of first-degree murder. The mental health challenges he faced in recent years are likely to be central to his legal defense.

item.title: The Truth About Weight-Loss Drugs Like Ozempic: You Probably Need Them Forever
item.description: Many people who use these medications don’t want to stay on them long term. But research has repeatedly shown that quitting the drugs means gaining back weight.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Iran’s Regime Is Losing Its Greatest Weapon: Fear
item.description: The bulwark of Iranian oppression is fear. The latest round of demonstrations shows it has been breached.
item.dc:creator: Abbas Milani
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Getty Images

item.title: 2 Polling Experts on How the ICE Shooting Is More Trouble for Trump
item.description: The general sense of the world being chaotic does not necessarily help Trump.
item.dc:creator: Kristen Soltis Anderson, Nate Silver and John Guida
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Alexander Brothers Accuser Was Found Dead Last Year, Authorities Say
item.description: The death of Kate Whiteman, whose accusation of sexual assault against Oren and Alon Alexander opened a floodgate of similar allegations, is under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Matias J Ocner
item.media:description: Alon Alexander, right, and his twin brother, Oren, left, in court in December 2024. Kate Whiteman accused them of sexually assaulting her in 2012.

item.title: Leonard D. Jacoby, 83, Dies; Brought Legal Services to the Masses
item.description: He and Steven Z. Meyers opened their first low-cost legal clinic in 1972. Within a decade, they had revolutionized the legal industry, and Jacoby & Meyers had become a widely known brand.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: California’s Pacific Coast Highway Fully Reopens After Three Years
item.description: The famed highway reopened this week after consecutive landslides shuttered two sections of the road in Big Sur and forced major repairs.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
